content.raw:
Video of the demo vehicle in action: https://drive.google.com/open?id=0B_WCOb_4cMD7TVowMVlUSG5GbG8 .

This method is only for non-deformable tracks, but it is pretty fast - on my 4-years-old notebook Core i7 it runs 10x realtime.
content.html:
Video of the demo vehicle in action: https://drive.google.com/open?id=0B_WCOb_4cMD7TVowMVlUSG5GbG8 .

This method is only for non-deformable tracks, but it is pretty fast - on my 4-years-old notebook Core i7 it runs 10x realtime.

content.raw:
Hi @peci1 , thanks for the contribution, that video looks awesome! I'm going to try this soon!

Answering some of your questions:

* Since you didn't change any Gazebo API / ABI, you could even target this to gazebo7 if you want. That is a long term support version.
* I think the `LoadParam` function is a great idea! This could probably go into SDFormat.
* Apparently [there isn't](http://stackoverflow.com/a/4609795) an out-of-the-box signum in C\+\+, but we could add one to `ignition::math::Helpers`
* I think it should be fine for the model to be embedded into the world as you put it, since it's an example and it's composed of simple shapes.
* As for generating models programmatically, an option is to use embedded ruby, [here](#!/osrf/gazebo_models/src/ae8c18c22b4e3a7b7d4bd86f53bd466141c27408/cart_front_steer/)'s an example from the model database.
content.html:
Hi @peci1 , thanks for the contribution, that video looks awesome! I'm going to try this soon!

Answering some of your questions:

  • Since you didn't change any Gazebo API / ABI, you could even target this to gazebo7 if you want. That is a long term support version.
  • I think the LoadParam function is a great idea! This could probably go into SDFormat.
  • Apparently there isn't an out-of-the-box signum in C++, but we could add one to ignition::math::Helpers
  • I think it should be fine for the model to be embedded into the world as you put it, since it's an example and it's composed of simple shapes.
  • As for generating models programmatically, an option is to use embedded ruby, here's an example from the model database.

content.raw:
Thanks for comments, Louise.

* Gazebo 7 is unfortunately a bit trickier, since I need to `#include <gazebo/ode/contact.h>` in `SimpleTrackedVehicle.cc` to get access to `dContact`. In G7, the ODE headers were not moved under the `gazebo/ode` include path, which makes it error-prone when there is a system install of ODE present. I was able to hack this in my G7 build file using:
```
#!cmake
list(GET GAZEBO_INCLUDE_DIRS 1 GAZEBO_INCLUDE_HACK)
include_directories(${Boost_INCLUDE_DIR} ${GAZEBO_INCLUDE_DIRS} ${GAZEBO_INCLUDE_HACK}/gazebo  ${catkin_INCLUDE_DIRS})
``` 
but that's not ideal I'd say.

* I can create the `LoadParam` and `signum` PRs. I assume if I target them to the default branches of these libraries, this will be another show-stopper for G7.
* Ruby is tricky if you want to have URDF as the initial input. I seek for run-time model generation/editing. My idea was to allow the user to specify a placeholder link (used e.g. in URDF) that will be deleted when the model is loaded and substituted with a track generated by the plugin.
content.html:
Thanks for comments, Louise.

  • Gazebo 7 is unfortunately a bit trickier, since I need to #include <gazebo/ode/contact.h> in SimpleTrackedVehicle.cc to get access to dContact. In G7, the ODE headers were not moved under the gazebo/ode include path, which makes it error-prone when there is a system install of ODE present. I was able to hack this in my G7 build file using:
list(GET GAZEBO_INCLUDE_DIRS 1 GAZEBO_INCLUDE_HACK)
include_directories(${Boost_INCLUDE_DIR} ${GAZEBO_INCLUDE_DIRS} ${GAZEBO_INCLUDE_HACK}/gazebo  ${catkin_INCLUDE_DIRS})

but that's not ideal I'd say.

  • I can create the LoadParam and signum PRs. I assume if I target them to the default branches of these libraries, this will be another show-stopper for G7.
  • Ruby is tricky if you want to have URDF as the initial input. I seek for run-time model generation/editing. My idea was to allow the user to specify a placeholder link (used e.g. in URDF) that will be deleted when the model is loaded and substituted with a track generated by the plugin.

content.raw:
* Oh interesting, I hadn't noticed this was ODE-specific. Targeting Gazebo 8 should be fine. But now I'm wondering if there could be a way to make this physics-engine-agnostic… I'll need to look closer into the code for that
* Adding functions usually doesn't break ABI, so you can try adding `LoadParam `and `signum` into `sdf5` and \`ign-math3\` respectively, if you want. Those would be great contributions, but I wouldn't let them block this PR. Having the functions here is ok too.
* Oh I see, so you want to generate the track inside the plugin C\+\+ code? I've seen this being done before. Maybe a naive way to do it could be to have a world plugin which generates an SDF file and spawns a model from that, where that model has it's own model plugin.
content.html:
• Oh interesting, I hadn't noticed this was ODE-specific. Targeting Gazebo 8 should be fine. But now I'm wondering if there could be a way to make this physics-engine-agnostic… I'll need to look closer into the code for that
  • Adding functions usually doesn't break ABI, so you can try adding LoadParamand signum into sdf5 and `ign-math3` respectively, if you want. Those would be great contributions, but I wouldn't let them block this PR. Having the functions here is ok too.
  • Oh I see, so you want to generate the track inside the plugin C++ code? I've seen this being done before. Maybe a naive way to do it could be to have a world plugin which generates an SDF file and spawns a model from that, where that model has it's own model plugin.

content.raw:
* Yes, [it is very ODE-spcific](#!/osrf/gazebo/pull-requests/2652/added-support-for-tracked-vehicles/diff#Lplugins/SimpleTrackedVehiclePlugin.ccT44). If you'd like to search for support in other engines, what's needed is support for friction velocity in both first and second friction direction.
* Is there a mapping/wiki that would explicitly state "Gazebo 7 works with sdformat 5 and ign-math3" and so on? I'm a bit lost in these version numbers.
* What I do now is to compose a piece of SDF in a string, load it, and then attach the loaded link/joint to the existing model. It's not ideal, but it works. What's bigger problem is deleting links/joints. I've never managed to delete them completely including visuals. I suspect I need the create and publish a "visual disappeared" message, but I don't know how. I assume the model editor does it somehow, but I haven't investigated into that too much.
content.html:
• Yes, it is very ODE-spcific. If you'd like to search for support in other engines, what's needed is support for friction velocity in both first and second friction direction.
  • Is there a mapping/wiki that would explicitly state "Gazebo 7 works with sdformat 5 and ign-math3" and so on? I'm a bit lost in these version numbers.
  • What I do now is to compose a piece of SDF in a string, load it, and then attach the loaded link/joint to the existing model. It's not ideal, but it works. What's bigger problem is deleting links/joints. I've never managed to delete them completely including visuals. I suspect I need the create and publish a "visual disappeared" message, but I don't know how. I assume the model editor does it somehow, but I haven't investigated into that too much.

content.raw:
Hi,

I am trying to merge the changes to the source of Gazebo7 distributed in Ubuntu 16.04. I am having problems with the sdf::Element::<T>Get() function:


```
#!

/home/fjsanchez/gazebo-7.0.0+dfsg/gazebo/common/Plugin.hh:208:62: error: no matching function for call to ‘sdf::Element::Get(const string&, double&)’
               auto result = _sdf->Get<V>(_name, _defaultValue);

```
I think the function in the SDF library used by gazebo7 do not have support for default values. Also, in gazebo::physics::Link it cannot find the member BoundingBox and gazebo::physics::World do not have a member called Physics... Possibly more things are required to get it to work in G7 but I am new to Gazebo... any hint? Should I just move to Gazebo8 only to get that? What is the current plan for that PR?
content.html:
Hi,

I am trying to merge the changes to the source of Gazebo7 distributed in Ubuntu 16.04. I am having problems with the sdf::Element::<T>Get() function:

/home/fjsanchez/gazebo-7.0.0+dfsg/gazebo/common/Plugin.hh:208:62: error: no matching function for call to ‘sdf::Element::Get(const string&, double&)’
               auto result = _sdf->Get<V>(_name, _defaultValue);

I think the function in the SDF library used by gazebo7 do not have support for default values. Also, in gazebo::physics::Link it cannot find the member BoundingBox and gazebo::physics::World do not have a member called Physics... Possibly more things are required to get it to work in G7 but I am new to Gazebo... any hint? Should I just move to Gazebo8 only to get that? What is the current plan for that PR?

content.raw:
Hi Francisco,

getting this to work with G7 seems to be a lot of extra work. This PR is targeted at G8, where it should merge cleanly. If you're on 16.04, there's (IMO) no point in staying with G7.

Anyways, the following week, I should push a whole bunch of changes required by the reviewers (mainly tests), and then there's a chance this PR gets merged to the mainstream G8.

Tell me if you succeded ;)

content.raw:
I'm trying it on Ubuntu Trusty (I know it's officially unsupported, but I manually installed the missing libraries and I can compile and run G8).

These pragmas were actually added to avoid compiler warnings. If you have an idea how to do it better, please, tell me. 

The warnings I'm supressing are right in telling that I save a locally obtained reference to an instance attribute, which may live longer. But in this case, since the simulation is stopped and waiting for this method to finish, we can be (IMO) sure the referenced value will not be freed.
content.html:
I'm trying it on Ubuntu Trusty (I know it's officially unsupported, but I manually installed the missing libraries and I can compile and run G8).

These pragmas were actually added to avoid compiler warnings. If you have an idea how to do it better, please, tell me.

The warnings I'm supressing are right in telling that I save a locally obtained reference to an instance attribute, which may live longer. But in this case, since the simulation is stopped and waiting for this method to finish, we can be (IMO) sure the referenced value will not be freed.

content.raw:
The front cylinders look dislocated, was this done on purpose?

![](data/bitbucket.org/repo/jgXqbo/images/5154987-track.png)
content.html: The front cylinders look dislocated, was this done on purpose?

content.raw:
Partly. The outer dislocation is a bug. The inner dislocation is intentional - we use it to help laser filtering remove the tracks from scans. 

But this is definitely something the simplified model doesn't need.
content.html:
Partly. The outer dislocation is a bug. The inner dislocation is intentional - we use it to help laser filtering remove the tracks from scans.

But this is definitely something the simplified model doesn't need.

content.raw:
The inertia of the base link looks slanted to the side, was this modeled after a more complex vehicle? Maybe we can add a note about this somewhere.

![](data/bitbucket.org/repo/jgXqbo/images/3859307965-trackinertia.png)
content.html: The inertia of the base link looks slanted to the side, was this modeled after a more complex vehicle? Maybe we can add a note about this somewhere.

content.raw: You're right, our robot has an off-centered Ladybug LB-3 on top of the deck, which makes the inertia look this way. I forgot to update it in this simplified model.
content.html: You're right, our robot has an off-centered Ladybug LB-3 on top of the deck, which makes the inertia look this way. I forgot to update it in this simplified model.

content.raw:

content.html: So, here's the paper where we describe this simulation model: https://arxiv.org/abs/1703.04316 And a comparison video with other models: http://cmp.felk.cvut.cz/~peckama2/share/iros2017.mp4

content.raw: Well, I'm sorry for the bugs. These were wrong expressions inside `GZ_ASSERT` calls, which got completely ignored in my Release builds. Now I've set up a Debug build instead and fixed these bugs. So now it should (hopefully) compile fine.
content.html: Well, I'm sorry for the bugs. These were wrong expressions inside GZ_ASSERT calls, which got completely ignored in my Release builds. Now I've set up a Debug build instead and fixed these bugs. So now it should (hopefully) compile fine.

content.raw: Yeah I know, it's not very clear where to find these things. Plugin tests are usually integration tests which load a world that already contains the plugin. You can see an example for the harness plugin [here](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/4e250e782cf04f70d2db6ad885a59bf6186691af/test/integration/harness.cc?fileviewer=file-view-default).
content.html: Yeah I know, it's not very clear where to find these things. Plugin tests are usually integration tests which load a world that already contains the plugin. You can see an example for the harness plugin here.

content.raw:
@chapulina here we go, I've finished writing some unit and integration tests that should cover at least the basic functionality.

Further changes: 

* I cut out the keyboard control into a standalone plugin that converts keypresses to cmd_vel messages. Might be used/useful in other vehicle worlds.
* In the model with tracks faked by wheels I changed the way track velocity is applied, because the approach used before was ODE-specific.

Minor issues will be added as inline comments.
content.html:
@chapulina here we go, I've finished writing some unit and integration tests that should cover at least the basic functionality.

Further changes:

  • I cut out the keyboard control into a standalone plugin that converts keypresses to cmd_vel messages. Might be used/useful in other vehicle worlds.
  • In the model with tracks faked by wheels I changed the way track velocity is applied, because the approach used before was ODE-specific.

Minor issues will be added as inline comments.

content.raw: This assert should come before the `if` above

content.raw: Not sure if asserts are the best choice here. They won't be there on production and user errors wouldn't be caught. Maybe we should have `if`s and print errors instead.
content.html: Not sure if asserts are the best choice here. They won't be there on production and user errors wouldn't be caught. Maybe we should have ifs and print errors instead.

content.raw: Can we remove some of these debug statements? It's a bit spammy right now. Also, I think we could make more use of `gzmsg` for notifications, `gzwarn` for warnings that something might be different from what the user expected, and `gzerr` for errors which will make the plugin fail.
content.html: Can we remove some of these debug statements? It's a bit spammy right now. Also, I think we could make more use of gzmsg for notifications, gzwarn for warnings that something might be different from what the user expected, and gzerr for errors which will make the plugin fail.

content.raw:
It seems we have different rules of thumb on when to choose which debug level. I thought that `gzdbg` should print enough information to allow the user to basically debug the plugin even without looking into the source code.

Also, I don't fully understand your point in the second sentence. First, you tell the logging is a bit spammy, and then you tell we should do more logging? Or should I understand it like "use less `gzdbg`s, use the other log levels instead"?
content.html:
It seems we have different rules of thumb on when to choose which debug level. I thought that gzdbg should print enough information to allow the user to basically debug the plugin even without looking into the source code.

Also, I don't fully understand your point in the second sentence. First, you tell the logging is a bit spammy, and then you tell we should do more logging? Or should I understand it like "use less gzdbgs, use the other log levels instead"?

content.raw: Sorry for not being clear, but yeah, I meant that if we're going to print anything, I'd use less `gzdbg` and more of the other levels. But again, this is just my subjective opinion, feel free to ignore it. We do have other plugins which print `gzdbg`s.
content.html: Sorry for not being clear, but yeah, I meant that if we're going to print anything, I'd use less gzdbg and more of the other levels. But again, this is just my subjective opinion, feel free to ignore it. We do have other plugins which print gzdbgs.

content.raw:
Wouldn't this be too spammy? In my view, a lot of plugins use default values, and I personally wouldn't like to see the log full of messages just about using default values.

It is true that most plugins don't have good documentation about the SDF parameters they take, so the only way to tell what's a parameter used for is actually looking into the source code of its implementation. Printing the default values to `gzmsg` might help a bit when the user is confused about what value is actually used, but I think `gzdbg` does almost the same thing.
content.html:
Wouldn't this be too spammy? In my view, a lot of plugins use default values, and I personally wouldn't like to see the log full of messages just about using default values.

It is true that most plugins don't have good documentation about the SDF parameters they take, so the only way to tell what's a parameter used for is actually looking into the source code of its implementation. Printing the default values to gzmsg might help a bit when the user is confused about what value is actually used, but I think gzdbg does almost the same thing.

content.raw:
Yeah I think they're both spammy actually, especially since we [don't support](#!/osrf/gazebo/issues/1705/add-optional-level-to-verbose-flag) choosing verbosity levels. No matter what we use, it will show up when running with the `--verbose` flag.

To me it just feels like debug statements should be used to help development and tests, but not for production. That's just my subjective interpretation though, I don't think we have official guidelines for this. The main practical difference between them is that `gzdbg` prints the file name and line, while `gzmsg` doesn't. If our objective is to inform users, I think the line number is not relevant...
content.html:
Yeah I think they're both spammy actually, especially since we don't support choosing verbosity levels. No matter what we use, it will show up when running with the --verbose flag.

To me it just feels like debug statements should be used to help development and tests, but not for production. That's just my subjective interpretation though, I don't think we have official guidelines for this. The main practical difference between them is that gzdbg prints the file name and line, while gzmsg doesn't. If our objective is to inform users, I think the line number is not relevant...

content.raw:
I wanted to test some of the protected methods in Plugin, so I wrote a plugin extending ModelPlugin and want to put the ASSERTS there. But since it is running outside the main test thread, GTest doesn't care about these asserts. This is a way to at least notify the main thread that something went wrong (but we can't tell, what, so I just print it to gzerr).

I asked for a better solution here: https://stackoverflow.com/questions/46394041/gtest-expect-no-fatal-failure-for-spawned-threads , but no answer so far.
content.html:
I wanted to test some of the protected methods in Plugin, so I wrote a plugin extending ModelPlugin and want to put the ASSERTS there. But since it is running outside the main test thread, GTest doesn't care about these asserts. This is a way to at least notify the main thread that something went wrong (but we can't tell, what, so I just print it to gzerr).

I asked for a better solution here: https://stackoverflow.com/questions/46394041/gtest-expect-no-fatal-failure-for-spawned-threads , but no answer so far.

content.raw:
Hey @peci1, 

i have used you code to simulate a robot with 2 tracks and 4 flippers in gazebo 7. I modified the plugin, so that the variable "tracks" of SimpleTrackedVehiclePlugin can now store 6, instead of 2 LinkPtr's. Also BELT_CATEGORY, ROBOT_CATEGORY and, on the left side, LEFT_CATEGORY will be set on the flippers. Everything works on simple surfaces, but i found some bugs:

If the robot is driving/rotating e.g. on ramps, std::swap() (used in SimpleTrackedVehiclePlugin::DriveTracks) will be triggered. This causes the friction direction to point in the opposite direction. I have fixed this by setting beltDirection to -beltDirection, if std::swap has been used before. You can see the bug in the following video. The result of frictionDirection will be displayed as markers in rviz, with the length of the calculated value of motion1. If motion1 is not equal to zero, the arrows will become red. Also every contact point on the tracks is shown by a blue sphere. The linear and angular velocity, which i have manually controled with a controller, will be visible in the console: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=u1lSbLIL9a4 In that example video i'am driving the robot onto aramp, and then just turn. But as you can see, the robot is moving sideways, instead of turning.

There is also a second bug. When the chassis touches the surface, and the tracks have no contact, the simulation will become really unstable and the robot will fly away. Have you encounterd a similar problem? You can see this in this video (the first bug is already fixed in this video, that's why the robot can now rotate on the ramp): https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=oPy5BFjr4g4
content.html:
Hey @peci1,

i have used you code to simulate a robot with 2 tracks and 4 flippers in gazebo 7. I modified the plugin, so that the variable "tracks" of SimpleTrackedVehiclePlugin can now store 6, instead of 2 LinkPtr's. Also BELT_CATEGORY, ROBOT_CATEGORY and, on the left side, LEFT_CATEGORY will be set on the flippers. Everything works on simple surfaces, but i found some bugs:

If the robot is driving/rotating e.g. on ramps, std::swap() (used in SimpleTrackedVehiclePlugin::DriveTracks) will be triggered. This causes the friction direction to point in the opposite direction. I have fixed this by setting beltDirection to -beltDirection, if std::swap has been used before. You can see the bug in the following video. The result of frictionDirection will be displayed as markers in rviz, with the length of the calculated value of motion1. If motion1 is not equal to zero, the arrows will become red. Also every contact point on the tracks is shown by a blue sphere. The linear and angular velocity, which i have manually controled with a controller, will be visible in the console: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=u1lSbLIL9a4 In that example video i'am driving the robot onto aramp, and then just turn. But as you can see, the robot is moving sideways, instead of turning.

There is also a second bug. When the chassis touches the surface, and the tracks have no contact, the simulation will become really unstable and the robot will fly away. Have you encounterd a similar problem? You can see this in this video (the first bug is already fixed in this video, that's why the robot can now rotate on the ramp): https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=oPy5BFjr4g4

content.raw:
Hi @Flipse789 , good to hear you more or less successfully use this plugin.

Regarding the first bug: it seems I can't get to a case where the swap would trigger in my scenarios. Could you share your world files? Nevertheless, it seems it makes sense to flip some vectors if the order of the bodies changes. However, it seems to me it'd be more proper the negate the contact normal, which would then affect more parts of the code that also access the contact normal data...

And regarding the second one - I can't replicate the behavior you describe. I tried it both in [Gazebo 7](https://vimeo.com/243098476) and [Gazebo 8](https://vimeo.com/243098480), and the problem doesn't manifest. Is the weight and inertia of your robot correct? Mine weighs about 20 kg, which adds a lot of stability.
content.html:
Hi @Flipse789 , good to hear you more or less successfully use this plugin.

Regarding the first bug: it seems I can't get to a case where the swap would trigger in my scenarios. Could you share your world files? Nevertheless, it seems it makes sense to flip some vectors if the order of the bodies changes. However, it seems to me it'd be more proper the negate the contact normal, which would then affect more parts of the code that also access the contact normal data...

And regarding the second one - I can't replicate the behavior you describe. I tried it both in Gazebo 7 and Gazebo 8, and the problem doesn't manifest. Is the weight and inertia of your robot correct? Mine weighs about 20 kg, which adds a lot of stability.

content.raw:
Thanks for the quick reply.
I simplified my robot model, so that i can send it to you, but now i'am unable to replicate bug 1. I will try it tomorrow again...

I have investigated bug 2 a bit more, and it seems that it only happens on models, which have meshes for collision. If i try to build a similar ramp out of simple boxes, everything works good. I have uploaded a second [video](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=5O6IGyxtvx0), where you can see a similar behavior, caused by other obstacles. I have uploaded the used sdf model in my [dropbox](https://www.dropbox.com/sh/x3ww19b4pqri3dp/AAByE6Dtp_C9T7QCJaHbIWM-a?dl=0), you can find it in the "object_robocup_metalbar" folder. I also uploaded my robot model, it it is written as a xacro xml file and launched by "getjag_new/launch/getjag_world.launch". Your can also see the source code, which i modified, located in "getjag_new/src/"  - I don't think the inertia or weight is causing this issue, because i tested the same robot with wheels, behaving normal. I guess it has something to do with my meshes, used for the collision, but then it would also affect the wheeled version...
content.html:
Thanks for the quick reply. I simplified my robot model, so that i can send it to you, but now i'am unable to replicate bug 1. I will try it tomorrow again...

I have investigated bug 2 a bit more, and it seems that it only happens on models, which have meshes for collision. If i try to build a similar ramp out of simple boxes, everything works good. I have uploaded a second video, where you can see a similar behavior, caused by other obstacles. I have uploaded the used sdf model in my dropbox, you can find it in the "object_robocup_metalbar" folder. I also uploaded my robot model, it it is written as a xacro xml file and launched by "getjag_new/launch/getjag_world.launch". Your can also see the source code, which i modified, located in "getjag_new/src/" - I don't think the inertia or weight is causing this issue, because i tested the same robot with wheels, behaving normal. I guess it has something to do with my meshes, used for the collision, but then it would also affect the wheeled version...

content.raw:
Cheers @Flipse789 after some time. Today I "managed" to reproduce the issue with a rather simple scenario - I substituted an obstacle composed of a few boxes with just a single cylinder. And for some reason this cylinder started to be the first collision body when colliding with main tracks (but not flippers). I think I once tried to track down where is this collision body order given, and I think it looks like it's "random" (but consistent, as you can see).

I implemented a fix that tries to be more "intelligent" and might address both of your issues. Basically, instead of just flipping the normal when the track is not the first collision body, it makes sure that in any case the normal points "inside the track". So I think it should work well even on mesh surfaces with flipped normals.

If you have time, could you please test it and report your findings?
content.html:
Cheers @Flipse789 after some time. Today I "managed" to reproduce the issue with a rather simple scenario - I substituted an obstacle composed of a few boxes with just a single cylinder. And for some reason this cylinder started to be the first collision body when colliding with main tracks (but not flippers). I think I once tried to track down where is this collision body order given, and I think it looks like it's "random" (but consistent, as you can see).

I implemented a fix that tries to be more "intelligent" and might address both of your issues. Basically, instead of just flipping the normal when the track is not the first collision body, it makes sure that in any case the normal points "inside the track". So I think it should work well even on mesh surfaces with flipped normals.

If you have time, could you please test it and report your findings?

content.raw:
Hi @peci1 , I am collaborating with the Gazebo team and I would like to help to get this PR merged.  
  
The only concern that I have is this [hack for gazebo 8](#!/osrf/gazebo/pull-requests/2652/added-support-for-tracked-vehicles/diff#Lplugins/SimpleTrackedVehiclePlugin.ccT125). Gazebo 8 is at EOL and this PR targets gazebo 9. Can I ask you to remove it? There is no point to add a hack that is no longer required in this and future versions.  
  
There are some minor style issues from the [codecheck](http://gazebosim.org/tutorials?tut=contrib_code&cat=development#Style). Here is the list:

```

./plugins/SimpleTrackedVehiclePlugin.cc:290:  Line ends in whitespace.  Consider deleting these extra spaces.  [whitespace/end_of_line] [4]

./plugins/SimpleTrackedVehiclePlugin.cc:316:  Line ends in whitespace.  Consider deleting these extra spaces.  [whitespace/end_of_line] [4]
./plugins/SimpleTrackedVehiclePlugin.cc:317:  Line ends in whitespace.  Consider deleting these extra spaces.  [whitespace/end_of_line] [4]
```
